column1: Will the Scottish National Party win a majority of seats in the next Scottish Parliament election?
column6: ['Elections and Referenda', 'Non-US Politics']
Albe seems to be a busted flush and Labour and the Tories are swapping votes between themselves. However, a lot of seats are maginal so I am cautiously optimistic that the answer will be yes.

Last forecast: Sinking or swimming at this point on an SNP majority. FWIW the most recent two polls listed in the link are higher for SNP than the previous iterations: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Scottish_Parliament_election

Brexit is highly unpopular in Scotland. Johnson has been blatantly rude about Scottish politicians. And, like most of the other nations in the UK, Scotland is tired of seeing the things they want to do nixed by the Conservative government. Labor is not much of a factor in these elections anymore.
https://www.bbc.com/turkce/haberler-dunya-57043028
2/3s feels right, will put neck out and say they will get 65 exact but error margin slim.
Thanks to @jayb (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1273011) for some useful, albeit conflicting info, and @Juliabizz (https://bit.ly/3tmK10K) and @Mark_T (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1272914)
More conflicting polls (etc.):

Polling (Savanta ComRes vs YouGov, Ipsos Mori etc.) appears unreliable as a hard indicator for this question's razor thin margin call of "majority or not" so it should only be seen as a measure of "it'll be really close" (within 1 or 2 seats either way) [1 and 2].
https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/scottish-nationalists-unlikely-win-majority-poll-indicates-2021-05-05/
Late polls may be indicating a better possibility of an SNP majority:
Based on the late-deciding voters breaking for the SNP, sure seems like it.
Revising down inline with the odds, and reflecting the effectiveness of media operations.

Revising my prediction upwards. There seems to have been an increase in support for the SNP in the last few days which I wasn't expecting. Furthermore there is a record breaking amount of people registering to vote, with the areas seeing the biggest increase being the areas with large non UK populations (who have recently been enfranchised and typically are more pro independence/SNP than those born within Scotland).
Full Forecast: https://globalguessing.com/metaculus-mondays-vol13/
So what has changed? Support for SNP based on Politico's poll of polls has slightly declined, based on which I had downgraded the prob by a couple of points.
Multiple recent polls suggesting drop in SNP support. Seems increasingly unlikely they will have an absolute majority of 65 seats although still within margin of error.

Moving down a little in the final week with the Greens potentially eating enough of the SNP's vote to steal the crown of a majority from them (whilst still leaving a collective majority for independence as part of the aforementioned "F You!" vote).
Sticking to 50% - Latest polling showing little movement - final debate on the 4th May https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-56969880
Recent polls seem to be swinging back and forth re likelihood of an SNP majority: https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/snp-independence-hopes-knife-edge-scottish-holyrood-elections-3v8xpb3z5
Ach.
The source is far from non biased but thought this article may be of interest to some:

Sticking at 50% even though crowd says higher. The SNP not seemingly gaining in momentum and Greens maybe getting a few more of the Regional List seats. https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2021/may/01/scotland-stands-at-the-crossroads-independence-holyrood
https://twitter.com/BritainElects/status/1388131356870430723
The will be the governing party but the chances of a majority are slimming.
Leaning to one side of the fence to lower the SNP's odds to 48%.

The latest polls show a loss of momentum with the political parties. There has been a rise in profile for the new Labour leader, Anas Sarwar and is proving to be popular. Events in Westminster have overshadowed this election and Sir John Curtice appears to backing off from his two seat majority of a few days ago. The Indy Ref vote also appears to be diminishing from its 50% ‘Yes’ vote. All I all too close to call. 50%/50%.
The polls seem to indicate it is close but central expectation should be no majority for SNP. One example: https://ballotbox.scot/
That seems pretty obvious. The fallout from Covid and brexit will lead to independence and for that stands the SNP.
https://www.bbc.com/turkce/haberler-dunya-57043028

Could definitely go either way, and it will be very close to the required 65 seats whichever side it falls on. If you take the polls at their word then it is very difficult to justify assigning over 50% on this.

This most recent Savanta Comres poll; https://2sjjwunnql41ia7ki31qqub1-wpengine.netdna-ssl.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Final_38028217-Scotland-Poll-Scotsman-20210428_Private__.pdf suggests a distinct drop-off in SNP popularity. Having read similar from other polls, I am reducing my forecast.
Some recent polls aren't appearing strong for chances of an outright SNP majority: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Scottish_Parliament_election

Keeping my prediction the same. The only movement in the polls in the last month seems to be a slight reduction in support for the SNP on the constitutioncy, and a large shift towards the greens on the all important list. Furthermore I am still confident that SNP supporters will turn out slightly less on the day. In part due to a lack of enthusiasm for an increasingly lackluster government (for many independence is the only motivation to still vote for them) but also due to the historical turn out trends amongst the demographics which the SNP gets most of its support. Going by the granularity of the polling it seems that the most motivated by the independence issue isn't young Independence supporters, it's old supporters of the Union. Therefore the increased talk of another ref may have a greater positive impact on those voting for unionist parties than it does amongst much of the SNP vote base.
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Scottish_Parliament_election

Judging by this recent article by Prof Curtice; https://bbc.in/3e1dj0y, an SNP majority is not assured. Hence, I am going back to @Juliabizz 's forecast. @Mark_T it seems that the polls Prof Curtice is using have been published after the Ipsos Mori one (https://bit.ly/32SZivm) you referred to in your most recent forecast.

The latest Survation poll shows SNP gaining 67 seats, which gives them a majority in Holyrood. Also importantly is the opinion of Professor Sir John Curtice that gives the SNP a majority of five seats. The current issues concerning Boris Johnson might have some effect on Scottish voters, although Westminster and the Prime Minister are overly popular anyway where the SNP consider Boris Johnson to be an asset.

And back up again with the release of the Ipsos Mori poll on Scottish Elections [1] and the “Tarring and feathering" of the Clown Prince south of the wall not showing any signs of abatement any time soon.
Adjusting down on new polling that looks less good for the SNP https://twitter.com/ballotboxscot/status/1386953196623519744?s=21
A recent poll indicates a possible SNP majority but it could be close:
Trawling through betting sites and news, SNP seem to have a better than an even chance of a majority, but not a dominant edge. 2/3 seems fair, but there is enough uncertainty to revise it to 60%
Tory sleaze allegations will probably depress their votes in the regional lists, making it that bit easier for the SNP
The scandal about alex salmon will decrease snp share or snp turnout. Not enough to push snp out of power but less certain of having a majority

Deliberately stayed away from this for a few weeks so as to not overreact to individual events. Now recalibrated forecast from scratch based on current data and (hopefully) correctly weighted historical events.
Thanks for flagging the latest @bh4eh
@Tolga & @Mark_T

Via sources, seems questionable at the moment whether the SNP can secure an overall majority (on its own): https://www.ft.com/content/3ea5b867-9a3c-404e-b2f9-c644fee4e3bd https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Scottish_Parliament_election
https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/snp-scottish-election-poll-independence-b1835641.html%3famp
Recent poll had SNP at 70 seats, aggregate polling suggests 64-68

As has been pointed out by various forecasters and news articles, the Scottish electoral system is largely designed in a manner that will not produce a majority. And as @Tolga (https://bit.ly/3arU5yE) pointed out, two polls are showing SNP some seats short of a majority. Albeit there is likely to be a majority of pro-independence seats in Holyrood, most likely either with or without a formal coalition with the greens (https://bit.ly/3sE6Ah0), in terms of this question, or my interpretation thereof, the SNP would not have a majority of seats filled my SNP members.
Reducing confidence

SNP will do well in terms of constituency votes / seats. Tory sleaze and Labour fence sitting will lead to that outcome. Question is around the Regional seats then. The anti-indy coalition will target those votes to restrict the power of SNP to get a (big) majority.

@Juliabizz Sturgeon seems intent on dodging the economic reality and cost of independence? Or perhaps, relying on emotional appeal to the converted and hoping to pull the wool over the eyes of some wavering voters that may be inclined to vote for independence? See what you think? https://youtu.be/766HnfIIl-k & https://bit.ly/3eo2rJ9. Betfair is often as accurate as opinion polls but yet another 'unrecorded' ministerial meeting isn't likely to do SNP's reputation much good; https://bit.ly/3ahe5UV Unrecorded meetings aside, will the reality of the SNP's guarantees to Gupta / Greensil that will cost the taxpayer hundreds of millions be an issue for voters? I would have expected it to be so but apparently it's not an issue.
Remaining on the fence. Betting odds see SNP coming up just short.

Downgrading slightly based on latest polling. Still think an SNP majority is the most likely outcome, based largely on leadership polling. Nicola Sturgeon remains extremely popular. Like @Tolga I am surprised the crowd forecast has remained as consistently high as it has. STV is designed to produce non-majority governments.

Second poll in a row that has the SNP short of a majority, this time 2 seats short. https://www.believeinscotland.org/exclusive-greens-and-alba-flying-high-on-list-but-snp-majority-in-danger/ https://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/nicola-sturgeon-to-fall-short-of-majority-as-alex-salmonds-alba-party-deprives-snp-of-key-list-seats-poll-shows-3192641
Latest polling and debate performance suggests the field is tipped slightly in favour of the SNPs majority pitch at this moment.

Simply joining the crowd and partially supported by recent news flows. Although I do like the rationale of @Superduperuser. I see @Juliabizz is holding out and as @Mark_T points out, politics is incredibly fickle and often hard to judge
Happy to roll with the crowd on this one.
https://www.bbc.com/turkce/haberler-dunya-57043028

It's more likely the pro union vote is undervalued than overvalued. Due to an effect similar to 'shy tory' and the population of online polls. The demographics in support of the Union are also the demographics with the best track record of voting on the day. I feel that Sarwar's focus on Covid recovery and his high personal ratings will cut through with soft yes supporters In the final weeks of the vote. I also think it's fairly likely that Salmonds Alba party may conduct a little but of brand damage against the SNP in the final weeks. Finally the Scottish election system is designed to prevent majorities. As such I think it is unlikely that the SNP will get a majority, although they will be in government.

Recent poll predicts SNP will fall 1 seat short of a majority: https://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/nicola-sturgeon-to-fall-short-of-majority-as-alex-salmonds-alba-party-deprives-snp-of-key-list-seats-poll-shows-3192641

Things are starting to look better for the SNP, polling has been better for them recently and they look on course for a majority. I still think the crowd is overestimating the likelihood but I want to go a bit closer to the crowd now because I've been under for a while. https://news.sky.com/story/scottish-elections-sturgeons-snp-set-for-majority-but-salmonds-alba-unlikely-to-get-single-seat-sky-news-poll-12268966
As is often the case in politics, there appear to be two likely outcomes which are too close to call just yet. Even though the election is less than 4 weeks away.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-04-07/snp-seen-winning-record-majority-in-scottish-vote-poll-shows
Increasing estimate, following statement from Ipsos Mori poll of 1038 people by phone.
Awaiting further well-sampled polls, but the potential Alba dent seems overbaked currently.

I wonder if Sturgeon is trying to 'buy' some critical votes? Perhaps she's feeling a little less sure of herself after the recent trying months? See https://bbc.in/3u6XYAx Although she claims the SNP is not divided, https://bbc.in/3fIDw4Z, one has to question that statement. Particularly in the light of some defections to Salmond's new Alba Party.And while the recent crisis around sexual harassment is a sensitive topic, I wonder if this statement about changing the 'not proven' law in Scotland is perhaps her attempt to redeem her reputation amongst voters that are reconsidering supporting her because of the atrocious handling of the Salmond affair? See https://bbc.in/3sW9uyK.

Raising forecast for now in part on SNP's apparent increase between last month's and this month's Sunday Times poll https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Scottish_Parliament_election

https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/nationalists-on-course-to-win-supermajority-g05l8c0st Curtice forecasts 65 seats (a majority of just 1) for the SNP based on a recent poll which includes the two new opposing political parties set up by current Russia Today employees.

Some analyses of the regional seats suggest Alba could only deny at most a couple or so seats from the SNP, so they will not be the most decisive factor in this question, instead it will be the SNP's own popularity and that of independence, so I revert more towards my pre-Alba forecast. At current levels of support it looks like the SNP have around a 50:50 shot, but I think it is more likely than not that their support falls another 1-5 percentage points over the course of the campaign, as basically many of their arguments are deeply flawed this time around (which may be exposed), and at least in the Labour party the new leadership, which most Scots will still be unfamiliar with, can only be an improvement on the old leadership.

Recent polls have been analysed by Survation that suggest that the Alba party may collect up to eight seats in the forthcoming Scottish elections. Were Alba to gain 7% of the vote, the losers would be the Conservatives, Labour and Greens leaving the SNP seat count unchanged. Most of the reporting on the polls appear to concentrate on the resultant referendum/independence majority, rather than the SNP seats. Polling suggests a narrow majority (65-70)or falling short by one seat. 65 required for a majority. The popularity of Salmond, after the recent criminal and civil trials plus the various enquiries, may be in question, but Alba has seen some six significant crossovers from the SNP. Scotland has a constituency and regional political voting system of some complexity that adds proportional representation to the mix that tends to aid minority parties if their voters are geographically widespread. Salmond appears to be gaming the system to reinforce the independence vote while maintaining his ‘thorn in the side’ to Sturgeon (SNP). If this manages to take seats of the minority parties, it could give the SNP the slender majority it requires to push forward its demand for a second referendum. Is tactical voting effective? The voters could vote for the SNP as an anti-Westminster, anti-Bexit vote, but vote No in the referendum.

There are no alternative parties in Scotland which look out for the Scottish people. Labour does not care about workers, the Tories does not care about anything north of the Midlands and Lib Dem doesn't look like they will be able to do a miracle.
There has been recent dip in SNP poll numbers reducing to 85%

It feels very wrong to make such a drastic change, but: (1) since the majority was only ever to be a thin one, Alba's creation is likely to have an outsized impact on the chance of a clear majority, even if the impact is limited to the regional vote. Yet Salmond polls poorly in Scotland and many SNP voters will surely (a supposition based on the absence of polling data) be unlikely to risk their party's majority, so I do not see this as bringing the chances of an SNP majority to 0. (2) Even more significant is the steady decline in SNP support since January highs when I previous made a projection. A continuation in this downward trend would indeed suggest a majority is out of reach.
Updated to account for my views of a few minutes ago and as below.

The announcement by Salmond of the new Alba party is likely to be a double-edged sword. By his own admission, he's 'gaming' the Holyrood MMP and STV voting system, which is slightly unusual; see https://bit.ly/31wTqXU. From the perspective of someone championing independence for Scotland, Salmond's motivation is logical and understandable. The internecine conflict with Sturgeon clearly makes Salmond persona non grata in SNP circles. See https://bbc.in/3fp7Mly Clearly any suggestion of Sturgeon and Salmond sitting around a table to mutually determine a strategy for independence is unlikely, Unless, of course, this is a very clever strategy and a major stitch-up. Unlikely in my view, as there is too much bad blood between the two.
Reducing due to formation of Alba.

- 2 from 100% There is a new pro independence party. So, this si a bad news for SNP, but i dont think it will hurt enough for the next election. https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/united-kingdom/ https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2021/mar/26/alex-salmond-launches-new-independence-focused-political-party-alba

Salmond is now forming a new 'pro-independence' party. Polls were already dropping some for SNP, securing an overall majority may be difficult: https://www.ft.com/content/3ea5b867-9a3c-404e-b2f9-c644fee4e3bd
Salmond is forming a party.

The polls show a clear lead for the SNP in May 2021 elections, but whether they will hold a majority of the seats is the question. With the Green party SNP can probably lead a minority government. Scotland did not vote for Brexit and this may have an effect on the wish for an independent Scotland and the desire to re-join the EU. Given the Catalonia experience in Spain, this may be blocked by EU Members not wishing to endorse breakaway communities. Sturgeon is perceived to have been successful in the fight against the Covid pandemic by beating Boris Johnson to relevant announcements. The public battle between her and Salmond has not been edifying but she has appeared to have come through unscathed with limited damage amongst SNP devotees. Sir John Curtice, the much-revered political analyst has stated that the SNP will have to gain converts to their cause as well as retain their existing voter base. Due to the natural dissatisfaction with Westminster over Edinburgh, I will fine tune my prediction with a narrow majority win for the SNP. https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-56247123 https://www.newstatesman.com/politics/scotland/2021/03/scottish-independence-poll-tracker-will-scotland-vote-leave-uk

@Juliabizz Thanks for some interesting references. After reading those and this, https://bit.ly/3lPFd1E, I am reducing my previous forecast. I have previously held that there was no apparent opposition to Sturgeon from any other party. Ross of the Tories has been trying although he overreached pushing his vote of no confidence prior to the release of the Hamilton report. Sarwar, the new Labour leader appears to be showing signs of a calculating cool head. So, perhaps there is opposition sufficient now to take some votes from Sturgeon, albeit the Scottish alternative voting system tends to make it harder for any party to shine through, as we have seen from the cobbled together coalitions that have kep the SNP in office for 14 years.

https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-56512440 Today’s pulse-taking from the BBC “...the SNP might just miss out on an overall majority - or might just make it. With the outcome of the election seemingly on such a crucial knife edge, it looks as though there will be an intense battle for every vote between now and polling day in May.”
Watching 2021 election opinion polls to see if their recent decline holds or changes for the SNP: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Scottish_Parliament_election
@Mark_T & @SE_Meyer

Schottland hat beim letzten Unabhängigkeits-Referendum nur für den Verbleib bei Großbritannien gestimmt um in der EU bleiben zu können. Durch den Brexit werden die Schotten so gegen ihren politischen Willen aus der EU gedrängt. Aufgrund dieser Szenarios strebt Nicola Sturgeon die Unabhängigkeit Schottlands von Großbritannien an und wird so eine starke Mehrheit für die SNP erringen können.
Scotland will depart GB sooner or later

Decreased because I just noticed others who see the same pessimism as me. I think a plurality is ~fairly~ (vague verbiage alert) more favorable than a majority. It is already below 50 and reached this point sooner than I predicted. Still chance of some kind of coalition building the few weeks prior to election.

Seems to be following a symmetrical rise and fall. If pattern continues, it should reach 50 and dip below threshold around May. It took 7 months-ish—plus or minus—to go from 50 and reach a peak, then begin falling again. It started falling almost 7 months ago. Because of talks about opposition on an election year, it may entirely be possible that the SNP wins a plurality but not greater 50 percent (a majority, as needed to resolve YES).
https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-56459301

I am quite skeptical because of the scandal of Nicola Sturgeon, who is due to face a vote of confidence next week if she does not resign herself: https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/politics/nicola-sturgeon-no-confidence-resign-23760944 https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2021/mar/19/sturgeon-should-resign-if-she-broke-ministerial-code-says-starmer
Crowd forecast comically high

https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2021/mar/18/nicola-sturgeon-misled-scottish-parliament-alex-salmond-inquiry-committee-finds?utm_term=e3f7e347753396aa0ec9d8b8ffcd33a3&utm_campaign=MorningBriefingUK&utm_source=esp&utm_medium=Email&CMP=morningbriefinguk_email
Lowering forecast some, for now:
Drop in polls of SNP due to allegations against Nicola Sturgeon.

Lowering based on new polling - Nicola Sturgeon on course to remain first minister but SNP's Holyrood majority in the balance, poll for Sky News suggests http://news.sky.com/story/sturgeon-on-course-to-remain-first-minister-but-snp-will-fall-short-of-holyrood-majority-poll-for-sky-news-suggests-12249350

The ongoing news flow regarding the spat between SNP and Salmond continues to be negative for both Sturgeon and the the SNP - https://bbc.in/30TSbBW The SNP also seems to be consistently polling lower - https://bit.ly/30Qvs9V . That said, the other parties are still some way off it seems. Furthermore, the raison d'etre for hte SNP, independence, seems to be losing appeal - https://bit.ly/3txaA3O. However, as they say, a week in politics is like a year...or something similar.
Based on the following, I am further reducing my forecast on this. See https://bit.ly/2P0FPp2 and https://bit.ly/3cEdkWl
https://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/scottish-elections-2021-snp-ahead-for-may-vote-but-new-poll-is-second-to-show-drop-in-support-for-independence-3146695
Reducing again due to Salmond/Sturgeon fall out, polling results and comparative success of vaccine strategy.
https://2sjjwunnql41ia7ki31qqub1-wpengine.netdna-ssl.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/SavantaComRes_TheScotsman_March2021Tracker_110321_Voting.pdf

Current consensus prediction of 90% seems a bit off. I was slightly surprised that they currently do not have a majority (SNP have 63 of 129 seats), and whilst Brexit may provide a reason for potential gains, the Salmond issue has revealed them as mortal politically. Now that the covid debate has moved on from being about the most effective restrictions it is now primarily about vaccine rollout where the Scottish government has no particular advantage it would seem. First pass guess 55%, to be refined when I look at some numbers.
Based on the following, I am lowering my forecast to be in the middle of @TJA and @Tolga

The SNP still seems likely to capture a majority of seats given that their poll performance is markedly better (by about 5-10 points) than before the 2016 election. The SNPs poll position seems to have dropped slightly in the last few months, but given that this is due to internal SNP strife over ministerial positions it is unlikely to change the outcome of the election. As an interesting corollary though, support for Scottish Independence seems to be waning. So it seems possible SNP may win the election, but SNP's planned referendum on Scottish independence may fail afterward. Scottish Independence would make a good GJOpen question. https://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/scottish-elections-2021-snp-ahead-for-may-vote-but-new-poll-is-second-to-show-drop-in-support-for-independence-3146695
Downgrading slightly based on: - Recent polling - Vaccine boost for UK gov - Internecine strife of the Salmond trial - New Labour leader being less useless than his predecessor
Sufficient time has passed since my January comment to venture a forecast: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1218547
Dropping to match the crowd in light of the amplified shenanigans that have engulfed the SNP in recent days.

I am beginning to waver....The Scottish Tories are still planning to proceed with a vote of no-confidence in John Swinney this week and in all likelihood, Nicola Sturgeon before too much longer - https://bbc.in/30n1ASk.
They are much closer on a majority (I.e more than half of seats) than the consensus implies. They almost certainly will be the largest party.

Sturgeon's 8 hour performance before the committee of MSPs yesterday has raised as many questions as it supposedly answered. Opinion appears to be divided as to the net result. Public opinion though, may be inclined to overlook the nuances of the situation and the details. The threat of a no confidence vote in her No 2 has forced yet more details of the legal opinion issued to her government, which her government ignored and which in turn cost the taxpayer £500k plus. So, after the events of yesterday, for the time being, I'll hold my position although as mentioned yesterday, Sturgeon's control over the SNP and hence the SNP's likelihood of a majority is currently quite tenuous. I suspect quite a lot will hang on how Salmond behaves in the next week or so. See https://bit.ly/3ri1bfR for some light reading.

I am not yet ready to review my forecast to meet the crowd although I am presented with an increasing temptation to do so. Sturgeon's public profile if looking increasingly wobbly IMO. See https://bit.ly/3sQj5ql / https://youtu.be/-vyoovGjCfo (if you have 5 odd hours and enjoy listening to her) and https://bit.ly/2NOnKdz. The apparently damning release of counsel's advice certainly does not make Sturgeon and her SNP government look honest and smelling like roses - https://bit.ly/3qjuPjy

- 5 It seem that Sturgeon will face a vote of confidence in relation with lies that she make about when she knew about sexual harassement case. I take some cautious about this press coverage, it's BBC in regard about Scotland. I dont think, it would be wise for the Scottish parlement to step down Sturgeon, in this covid-19 time. Conservative could be blame to fragilize the government in time of crisis.

Alex Salmond's testimony in Holyrood appears to have been pretty inconclusive as to whether there was a conspiracy in motion in 2018 to have him jailed and thus removed from the political landscape in Scotland. Albeit, it's not yet clear what purpose that would serve as both Sturgeon and Salmond are staunch supporters of independence. However, this spate may still evolve and seriously dent Sturgeon's credibility amongst voters. See https://bit.ly/3b4f9vP / https://bit.ly/3uLzEFJ / https://bit.ly/3b5f1fA/ https://bbc.in/3dV0ANa / https://bbc.in/3sDTvod / https://bbc.in/3sBYfuC

Increased confidence in likely majority based on latest polling and assessment of the current Salmond / Sturgeon storm in a teacup doing much long term harm come polling day (vs the potential undermining of messages that Johnson has shown a real talent for).

Regardless of the internal problems the SNP are facing, the alternative parties lack significant strength to challenge the SNP on a national scale. The Conservatives have been negatively impacted by the immediate impact of Brexit on fishing communities in several of their North Eastern support areas, Labour is in the middle of a leadership election and the Lib Dems do not have sufficient concentration to win many seats. As a result an SNP victory is a near certainty.
https://www.heraldscotland.com/news/19105030.snp-will-win-may-will-pyrrhic-victory/
Will review after Salmond's testimony on Wednesday.
I think they will get a majority but I am not convinced that as many want independence as the media suggests.
Nicola Sturgeon, Dr. Steve Pieczenik MD was in Italy in 1978 and is able to shed more light on Prime Minister Aldo Moro’s circumstances. Between you and Queen you might be able to work something out.

Is this the canary in the coal mine for Sturgeon? - https://bit.ly/37hBzHK Perhaps although I think Sturgeon will make it through the next 3 months. Possibly a bit battered and bruised but sufficiently whole to claim a majority victory.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-politics-scotland/scottish-support-for-independence-drops-poll-shows-idUSKBN2AB146 Interesting, but not likely to affect SNP's support significantly.

Thanks to Mark_T and his forecast (https://bit.ly/3aQWpyK) with the link to the Spectator article and his assessment of Sturgeon's almost unassailable position in Scotland. As Mark points out, Sturgeon's biggest threat is likely to come from her own party in the form of Alex Salmond and Joanna Cherry and her possible misleading of parliament about when and what she knew about Salmond's supposed dalliances that he's been acquitted from.

As I previously suggested, there really is little opposition to Sturgeon and hence every likelihood she will win a majority in May 2021. While it appears that the Scottish public is fairly evenly divided on the topic of independence from UK, Scottish nationalists have been the backbone of support for Sturgeon. Sturgeon has argued strongly that Scotland would be better off out of UK, independent and in the EU. This recent study from the London School of Economics suggests that costs to Scotland would be substantially more than the cost of Brexit. See https://bbc.in/3pNY4eC. This could dent Sturgeon's support across both sides of the divide.It will also raise the question again about how viable Scotland would be as an independent country and whether or not it would be feasible for Scotland to rejoin the EU. Or for that matter, with Scotland's significant deficit, if the EU would accept an application from Scotland as an independent country. Equally questions are being asked about Sturgeon's handling of the Covid situation in Scotland and her knowledge of Salmond's dalliances and if she was economic with the truth in the house. On balance, Sturgeon will, IMO, gain a majority although it may be a reduced majority.

The conventional wisdom right now is that the SNP will win a majority. Recent polling in the Scotsman Newspaper put the SNP on 71 seats, which is +8 from 2016 and two seats higher than their record 69 seats in 2011. That 2011 election paved the path for the independence referendum in 2014 that ultimately failed. Scottish independence will surely be a cornerstone of the SNP election strategy this time around. Polling shows independence support at 57% despite continued Westminster opposition. Some Tories have begun to float ideas on how to proceed but Boris Johnson has so far made it clear he would not support another referendum. This could solidfy support the SNP. Another issue has been COVID. SNP leader Sturgon and the Scottish government get high marks for their handling of COVID compared to Johnson and the UK government. It is something to keep an eye on. I am not sure they get to 71 seats, but right now I would put the SNP on 67-68 seats with a 71% of gaining a majority.

The SNP is on track to win 71 of 129 seats, further to a Scotsman newspaper poll in mid-January, a gain of 8 seats from its 2016 election result.[1] About 57% of Scottish voters favor independence, according to the same polling snapshot. SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon has promised to push for another referendum if they win a majority. The Scottish parliamentary system through its so-called "Additional Member System" creates a much closer and more direct relationship to public opinion in proportionally allocating seats than the Westminster system of "first past the post."[2] In this way, it seems to me, that many Scottish voters see a direct connection between voting SNP and rejecting the UK government's chaos and bungling of Brexit and COVID under Boris Johnson. The AMS method makes public opinion a much more reliable gauge of the outcome than in "first past the post" systems, in my view.
Polls suggest the possibility but I do not know how BREXIT experiences will influence realized vote so perhaps less room for confidence.

If we break the question down into the following parts: - how accurate are the polls? UK polling errors still would have the SNP polling well above 50% nationally. Nevertheless, there is less evidence with Scottish elections. -3% - How many target seats are there? The SNP has 10 target seats which require a swing of between 0.17 and 3.73 to win. The conservatives have 7 targets, 6 are SNP seats with a swing of 1.97 and 4.90 to win. The SNP need two more seats to win a majority. I couldn't find polling data for those 16 swing seats, but national polling suggests the SNP nationally are looking far stronger than in 2016. -2% - will the SNP be hit by internal conflict or a scandal If the SNP were hit by a scandal affecting turn out then they could fail to win more seats. Such a scandal/internal conflict might come due to disagreements over how to approach the independence vote. Sturgeon's concerns about international recognition of the independence vote are not shared by all. We are likely to see many events (court cases, meetings, etc.) on this topic before the election. -5% - could there be COVID and Brexit successes that are well communicated by Westminster There is a non zero chance of some major victory communicated as a Westminster success that persuades just enough people to not vote SNP. However, those same challenges are so large that the UK government, despite the PM's personal involvement in matters of the Union, will find it hard to also consider communicating it in Scotland. -1%

SNP appears headed for majority with approximately four months to go. There are, however, considerable opportunities for opponents to make inroads. With the UKs recent conclusion of BREXIT the next months is likely to greatly inform the Scots view of London. The pro-independence/anti-BREXIT SNP is likely to gain initial support as businesses and individuals struggle to adapt to their new reality, Scotland’s fishing industry being a particularly good example as fishermen are either staying in port or attempting to sail to now foreign ports to skirt delays along the traditional route. These hiccups are likely to subside and with it a rebalancing of support for SNP and independence. This may be compounded by London’s assertion that Scotland should delay another referendum until the 2050s, which could exacerbate Scot calls for self-determination. SNP is likely to win in a landslide, but opportunities exist for this not to come to fruition.

Some data: Since its inception the SNP has averaged 13.4% of votes, however this is a misleading statistic since they later merged with another party. Since that time they have pulled 19.8% of votes on average. Since 2001, the average has increased to 31.6%, barely under Labor's (since 2001) average of 32.3%. Labor has recently experienced massive drop of in voter turn out (since 2011), when SNP took a large share of votes (50%). Worth noting, the Labor party is currently engaged in "Open civil war" with the most recent leader stepping down. Lastly SNP has been polling Significantly ahead of Labor and conservative parties.

Opinion polls have placed the SNP at or above 45% in the regional vote and above 50% in the constituency vote on a regular basis since May 2020. The New Statesman's election forecast model predicts the SNP will comfortably achieve an overall majority, and polls on the issue of Scottish independence have now consistently given a lead to Yes/Leave/Independence since summer 2020. I do not anticipate a change in the leader Scottish Labour will result in an immediate improvement in electoral performance for the party. However, I anticipate that the successful rollout of the Covid-19 vaccine across the UK may result in a small poll increase for the Conservatives in advance of the scheduled May election, leading to a smaller majority for the SNP than is currently predicted.
Largest party in parliament already, aggregate suggests majority, Scottish fisheries disrupted due to Brexit will likely aid SNP due to consistently anti-Brexit stance

The upcoming Scottish election would appear to be more than just voting for their preferred political party but also a protest vote against Brexit (Scotland voted to remain in the EU trading bloc – 62%), a vote for independence (that appears to be gaining in acceptance -56%) and a rejection of the political elite in Westminster. There appears to be Teflon element to the Sturgeon government where the SNP is the most trusted concerning education, where there has been universal condemnation of the diminishing education system. Poverty and life expectancy in East Glasgow is also an issue for the SNP. Boris Johnson may have upset Scottish sensibilities by stating that devolution has been a disaster. By this, one assumes that the handing over limited powers to a Scottish legislature has been a mistake which, has probably reinforced independence ambitions. Therefore, the SNP will probably increase their share in the Scottish Parliament. However, there may be a future backlash when arguments are made as to the financial viability, type of currency (new countries have to join the Euro in the EU) and the English – Scottish border (consider the issues over the Eire- NI border {EU/UK} ) that independence would bring.
